Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Developing Antenna-Coupled Kinetic Inductance Detectors to Enable Next Generation CMB Experiments
Award.AbstractNarration:
The team will design, build and demonstrate arrays of Kinetic Inductance Detectors (KIDs). A KID contains a very cold, resistance-free device. That device changes its properties when it "sees" the Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB), the faint signal from the young Universe. Vast arrays of KIDs are needed for the next generation of CMB experiments. The team will also provide laboratory experience for undergraduates from underrepresented minorities and for high school students in the Chicago area.

The team's goals are: (1) Fabricate single-layer resonators to characterize film properties, measure the intrinsic noise level, and verify sensitivity scaling laws. (2) Couple the resonators to a simple antenna, to measure the response and dielectric  losses at millimeter wavelengths and to verify full coverage of the CMB atmospheric windows. (3) Test single-pixel multi-channel detectors coupled to wide-band log-periodic antennas, to verify background-limited operation under realistic conditions. (4) Conduct end-to-end laboratory tests of a demonstration KID array of about 2000 pixels. Future CMB experiments using KID arrays with millions of pixels will (a) precisely measure the number of neutrino species and the neutrino mass summed over those species, missing - but vital - information for testing theories of particle physics; and (b) dramatically improve searches for the primordial gravitational B-mode polarization that would prove that the Universe underwent the cosmic inflation posited by theorists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Measurement of the Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) - light from the early Universe which is now observable at millimeter wavelengths - have provided a wealth of information about the properties of the Universe and fundamental physics. To make further progress, very large arrays containing hundreds of thousands of extremely sensitive, polarized detectors are required. Fabricating and reading out such large focal planes using existing technology is a challenge.

The primary goal of this project was to demonstrate a prototype CMB detector based upon a recently developed technology: the Kinetic Inductance Detector (KID). The KID uses superconducting resonators whose frequency changes in response to absorbed radiation. They promise simpler fabrication, integration, and readout than existing technology, but have not yet been demonstrated on-sky for CMB observations. In order to fully demonstrate the capability of this technology and pave the way for future astronomical instruments, it is necessary to characterize the microwave and mm-wave properties of the materials used in fabrication, demonstrate the sensitivity required in the frequency bands at which the CMB can be observed, and show that a large scale array can be constructed with high yield and consistent properties.

We have demonstrated several new techniques and characterized materials that will be useful in building instruments. Our initial investigation into the use of atomic layer deposited titanium nitride (TiN) films for the construction of resonators showed promising properties and has lead to several publications and new applications. However, the poor repeatability of TiN properties lead us to move to the use of aluminum as a resonator material, which we have demonstrated has predictable and suitable properties. Addition material investigations included the mm-wave properties of silicon nitride dielectrics and niobium transmission lines. Finally, we developed a novel approach to connecting a transmission line to a KID, in which inverted microstrip connects directly to an aluminum resonator coupled to a niobium capacitor, which provides a simple way to reduce excess noise.

We design, constructed, and tested small prototype arrays consisting of seven optical pixels with lithographic antennas behind small lenses. These devices showed expected noise and response to radiation as well as expected beam patterns. However, we found they suffered from an unexpected response to stray light, that is, optical power entering the chip directly rather than through the antenna. Several designs were tested to mitigate this effect, with partial success. We therefore chose to replace the antennas with a metal feed horn coupled to a dual-polarization wide-band probe. These devices have performed as expected, reducing the sensitivity to stray light to a level which is difficult to measure and suitable for future CMB instruments. Prototype devices at two frequencies have now been tested, and we expect to continue this work in the future.

The final part of this program - the demonstration of a large array - has been delayed as a result of significant restrictions to cleanroom and lab access due to COVID-19. We have a preliminary array design and are exploring options to fabricate them in the near future.

In addition to the specific goals of this project, it has lead to a number of closely related developments. A slightly modified version of the horn-coupled KID we designed is planned for a new focal plane for the South Pole Telescope. This team, as well as collaborators at Argonne National Lab, are testing the first prototypes of these devices now using the hardware commissioned as part of this project.  The novel KID coupling scheme is being used currently in the development of narrow-band spectrometers as part of an independent project in our group. The titanium nitride work has lead to new work on the use of the non-linear kinetic inductance effect as a current sensor, as well as close collaboration with colleagues working on quantum computing.

The Broader Impacts component of this program is largely focused on student training. In particular, a partnership with the Leadership Alliance (LA) program which provides summer research experiences and ongoing engagement for undergraduates from under-served communities. We have hosted one LA student, as well as three NSF REU students. They successfully designed and have nearly completed the prototype for a novel current-measuring device based on the properties of our TiN films. We anticipate continuing to work with the LA program to complete this work as well as other projects once COVID-19 restrictions allow it. We have also provided significant training in all aspects of this science for two local undergraduates, two graduate students, and one postdoc. One of the graduate students will complete a PhD based on this work in June 2021. The postdoc is now in a senior position and is leading a project based largely upon extending this work to future instruments.
